metadata_frame: The following passage comes from An Outline of English Local Government, a novel published in 0 by Edward Jenks, an UK .
main_question:
The Justices compelled negligent parishes to do their duty, and helped the feeble parish with "rates in aid.” Later on, Settlement the Justices enforced the law of settlement by ordering removal. the removal from a parish of new-comers who seemed likely to come upon the rates. And, as we have seen, the position of the Justice in the Poor Law system remains almost untouched at the present day; [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact].

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]:
source_title: An Outline of English Local Government
answer_strings: although the appearance of factories and trades unions, county courts and Boards of Conciliation, have robbed him of much of his importance in industrial matters
although the absence of factories and trade unions, county courts, and Boards of Conciliation has left him with little importance in industrial matters

although the central Government may compel parishes to unite if it appears obviously better that they should do so, there are, as matter of fact, many large parishes which (either with or without special legislative sanction) still administer their own poor relief
though it by no means extinguished the individuality of the component parishes of a Union
however, some Justices began to advocate for reform due to growing public awareness of poverty's complexities
yet, in certain circumstances the Justices granted exemptions, allowing the retention of newcomers when the parish could not bear the burden of their rates
passage: The Justices compelled negligent parishes to do their duty, and helped the feeble parish with "rates in aid.” Later on, Settlement the Justices enforced the law of settlement by ordering removal. the removal from a parish of new-comers who seemed likely to come upon the rates. And, as we have seen, the position of the Justice in the Poor Law system remains almost untouched at the present day; although the appearance of factories and trades unions, county courts and Boards of Conciliation, have robbed him of much of his importance in industrial matters.
full_sentence: And, as we have seen, the position of the Justice in the Poor Law system remains almost untouched at the present day; although the appearance of factories and trades unions, county courts and Boards of Conciliation, have robbed him of much of his importance in industrial matters.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from An Outline of English Local Government, a novel published in 0 by Edward Jenks, an UK .
main_question:
The ChiefConstable of the county, with the approval of Petty Sessions, appoints the specified number of constables in each police district,¹ with a Superintendent at the head of each, and has even considerable powers of dismissal and punishment; but in these and most other matters, he is subject to the general control of the Joint Committee, which may, with the approval of the Secretary of State, organise and distribute the county force in such manner as to it may seem fit, providing for gradations of rank, pay, allowances, promotions, and other details. 1 Although there does not seem to be any direct statutory provision on the subject, the lines of the police district must follow those of the petty Sessional Division. THE STANDING JOINT COMMITTEE 181 Sessions But it is here very necessary to observe that, [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]. authority of Quarter Sessions and even of single Justices over individual constables has been specially retained by the County Councils Act.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]:
source_title: An Outline of English Local Government
answer_strings: although Quarter the general administration of the county force has been and transferred to the Joint Committee, the control and Justices
although the general administration of the county force remains with Quarter and the control and authority have not yet been transferred to the Joint Committee,

although its powers in relation to Parliamentary election matters have been transferred to its new rival, it is presumed that Quarter Sessions still retains the right of marking out its county into Petty Sessional divisions

though fixed by the watch committee, are subject to the approbation of the Council, though a court of quarter or petty sessions may, of its own discretion, order special rewards or compensation to be paid to a borough constable for special diligence, or for injuries received in the discharge of his duty
it is important to note that the actual day-to-day management of these districts falls under the purview of individual petty sessions

nevertheless, the Chief Constable’s powers are subject to the statutory oversight of the Quarter Sessions and individual Justices, whose authority over constables remains expressly preserved by the County Councils Act
